questions.question: What does monosyllabic diction accomplish?

choices.answer: Quickens the pace
gains our attention through its simplicity?
Confuses the reader
Adds complication through the dense wording

questions.question: What does polysyllabic diction do?

choices.answer: Quickens the story and plot development.
Adds to the story's exposition.
Helps with setting.
Slows the reader owing to the complicated wording.

questions.question: Euphonious diction is...

choices.answer: ugly words for ugly stuff.
Emotional wording.
always figurative.
pretty words for pretty stuff.

questions.question: A writer employs cacaphonous diction often to...

choices.answer: enhance the pretty mood.
enhance the ugly mood.
quicken the rising action.
speed us to the story's resolution.

questions.question: Literal diction is

choices.answer: difficult to understand
is easy to understand
is similar to concrete diction
is  something Mr. B will not ask us about much.

questions.question: Figurative Diction is important because...

choices.answer: it is simple and straightforward.
for its ease of reading.
it creates pictorial and sensory effects for the reader.
it accelerates the pace of our reading.

questions.question: Denotative diction is

choices.answer: rarely worth mining the depths of...
the dictionary definition of the word.
adds intriguing complications and meaning to a text.
requires strenuous analysis.

questions.question: Connotative diction is significant because?

choices.answer: It requires the reader to further ponder.
It requires the use of an updated dictionary.
It requires very little effort on behalf of the reader.
It shows the setting and time period of the text.

questions.question: Subjective diction will always contain...

choices.answer: Emotionless words
Emulsified words
Emotive words
concrete diction

questions.question: Choose the Objective Diction:

choices.answer: The sad student cried and cried.
Love is a complicated notion.
The sky is blue on sunny days.
Pat yelled and screamed...and screamed some more.

questions.question: Which one is in active voice (active diction)?

choices.answer: The food was eaten by me.
The mail was delivered.
I ate the food.
The ball shot through the sky after being hit by the batter.

questions.question: Which one is in passive voice?

choices.answer: I eat.
The elephant is a large mammal.
The committee will always take a long time to decide.
The base was stolen by the guy trying to steal the base.

questions.question: Concrete diction is easy because...

choices.answer: it's abstract, connotative, and subjective, too.
it's straightforward, simple narration, uncomplicated.
it deliberately slows the pace of our reading.
it is crucial in giving us proper characterization.

questions.question: Abstract diction is tough because it...

choices.answer: makes everything happen so quickly you have to pay attention
involves difficult concepts that require further pondering.
it's a weird type of art that I wouldn't consider really art
usually involves the physical setting, and setting is tough.

questions.question: Hyperbolic diction should catch our attention because it...

choices.answer: impacts the mood and tone of the text
is a deliberate exaggeration and we should consider why.
usually involves irony that must be unraveled.
is helpful in understanding the exposition of the story.

questions.question: We should note understated diction because it...

choices.answer: delves into abstract concepts.
reveals the exact setting of the text.
can reveal characterization.
influence the mood and tone of a piece.

questions.question: Pedestrian diction is...

choices.answer: common speech
complicated speech
emotional speech
abbreviated speech

questions.question: People who speak pedantically are...

choices.answer: showing off their erudition.
using simple, literal diction.
demonstrating a careless attitude toward expression.
probably making up for a deeply-seated inferiority complex.

questions.question: New diction should be noted because it...

choices.answer: is fun and fresh and hasn't been worn out yet.
helps the reader with the setting of the text.
doesn't have any scuff marks on it yet.
can't be cliched...yet.

questions.question: Archaic Diction is important because it...

choices.answer: is somewhat cacophonous-sounding.
often alludes to former times, thus inviting our attention.
is also often richly connotative and figurative.
is always literal and straightforward.

questions.question: Diction has levels. The first, formal, applies to...

choices.answer: abstract diction
literal diction
serious occasions, often linked with writing assignments.
is how I talk to my friends.

questions.question: Diction has levels. The second, informal, pertains to...

choices.answer: cacophonous diction only.
euphonious diction only.
connotative word choice.
pretty much the way I speak on a daily, routine basis.

questions.question: Vulgarity, which is non-standard diction, is an easy one because it..

choices.answer: is so commonly practiced on our campus.
adds to characterization and the authenticity of the story.
resulted in me getting in trouble whenever I demonstrate it.
changes the ratings of movies into the ones I usually see.

questions.question: Slang is non-standard diction, too. It...

choices.answer: is invented by teenagers so adults don't understand it.
changes the denotative and literal meanings of words hugely.
always involve abstract and difficult concepts.
creates polysyllabic words from monosyllabic words.

questions.question: Colloquial diction is non-standard, too. It usually involves expressions that are...

choices.answer: specific to certain geographical regions.
used to aid in characterization and setting.
highly concrete and literal.
often associated with new diction and, thus, science fiction

questions.question: Jargon is...

choices.answer: figurative language.
archaic language.
language specific to a certain group.
language specific to a geographical region.

questions.question: Assonance, consonance, and alliteration catch our attention because of the words'...

choices.answer: similarity in spelling.
similarity in meaning.
of the similarity in origin.
similarity in sound.
